statement.tex: \text{Find the integral of the function}\\ \sin^3 x \cos^3 x \\

step.context: \text{Let } f(x) = \sin^3 x \cos^3 x \\ \text{If the trigonometric identity, } \sin^2 x = 1 - \cos^2 x \\ \text{is applied on f(x) then, what can be substituted}\\ \text{with t to make f(x) more easily integrable}?
step.tex: \text{Substitue } \cos^2 x = t \implies -2 \sin x \cos x dx = dt
step.reason:
\sin^3 x \cdot \cos^3 x = (1- \cos^2 x)\cdot \sin x \cdot \cos^3 x \\ \text{Let } \cos x = t \text{ then, } -\sin x dx = dt \\
\begin{align} \implies (1- \cos^2 x) \cdot \cos^3 x \cdot \sin x &= -(1- t^2) t^3 \\ &= (t^2 -1) t^3 \end{align} \\
\therefore \int \sin^3 x \cos^3 x dx = \int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx

step.context: \text{Is the following evaluation of the integral}\\ I = \int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx \quad \text{correct}?
step.tex:
\begin{align} I &= \int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx \\ &= \int t^5 dx - \int t^3 dx \\ &= \dfrac{t^6}{6} - \dfrac{t^4}{4}+ C \\
\text{Putting } t &= \cos x \\ &= \dfrac{1}{6}\cos ^6 x - \dfrac {1} {4} \cos^4x + C \\ \therefore \int \sin^3 x \cos^3 x &= \dfrac{1}{6}\cos ^6 x - \dfrac {1} {4} \cos^4x + C \end{align}

\begin{align} I &= \int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx \\ &= \int t^5 dx - \int t^3 dx \\ &= \dfrac{t^5}{5} - \dfrac{t^3}{3}+ C \\ \text{Putting } t &= \cos x \\ &= \dfrac{1}{5}\cos ^5 x - \dfrac {1} {3} \cos^3 x + C \\ \therefore \int \sin^3 x \cos^3 x &= \dfrac{1}{5}\cos ^5 x - \dfrac {1} {3} \cos^3 x + C \end{align}
step.reason: \int x^n dx = \dfrac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C \\ \text{ where C is the constant of integration.}
